conclusion: Analyze forces and torques acting on the dipole in the magnetic field to find minimum initial angular velocity for orientation reversal.
Torque on dipole due to magnetic field is primary force causing rotation.
Torque is given by the cross product of magnetic moment and magnetic field.
Magnetic moment for dipole with charges +q and -q separated by distance d is -qd k.
Torque simplifies to (-qd k) x B in uniform magnetic field.
Dipole initially aligned with X-axis, magnetic moment points along negative Z-direction.
If B is in Y-direction, torque is qdB i.
Moment of inertia of dipole about center of mass is md^2.
Angular acceleration is torque divided by moment of inertia, resulting in qB/md.
Dipole must complete half a revolution (theta = pi) to reverse orientation.
Angular displacement theta as a function of time is omega_0 t - (1/2) alpha t^2.
At reversal, theta = pi leads to quadratic equation in t.
Quadratic equation is (qB/2md) t^2 - omega_0 t + pi = 0.
Real solution for t requires non-negative discriminant.
Taking square root gives omega_0 >= sqrt(qBpi/md).
Minimal initial angular velocity omega_min is sqrt(qBpi/md).
